content: - Christopher Columbus lands in Honduras.

- Spain begins conquest of Honduras, which is accomplished only in 1539 after bitter struggles with the native population and rivals representing Spanish power centres in Mexico, Panama and Hispaniola.
- Northern coast falls to British buccaneers; British protectorate established over the coast until 1860 while the Spanish concentrate on the inland area.
- Honduras gains independence from Spain but becomes part of Mexico.
- Honduras joins the United Provinces of Central America, which also include Costa Rica, El Salvador, Guatemala and Nicaragua.
- Honduras becomes fully independent.
- US becomes economically involved in Honduras, with the United Fruit Company controlling two-thirds of banana exports by 1913.
- Honduras under right-wing National Party of Honduras (PNH) dictatorship led by General Tiburcio Carias Andino.
- Colonel Osvaldo Lopez Arellano takes power after leading a coup.
- Brief but costly war with El Salvador over heavy immigration and disputed border.
- Lopez resigns after allegedly accepting a bribe from a US company.
- Colonel Juan Alberto Melgar Castro take power.
- Melgar ousted in coup led by General Policarpo Paz Garcia.
- General Paz signs peace treaty with El Salvador.
- Roberto Suazo Cordova of the centrist Liberal Party of Honduras (PLH) is elected president, leading the first civilian government in more than a century.

But armed forces chief General Gustavo Alvarez retains considerable power and Honduras becomes embroiled in various regional conflicts. US-run camps for training Salvadorans in counterinsurgency are set up on Honduran territory.
- US-backed Nicaraguan counter-revolutionaries, or Contras, launch operations to bring down Nicaragua's Sandinista government from Honduran territory.

- General Alvarez responds to increasing political unrest by ordering the detention of trade union activists and left-wing sympathisers. Death squads are allegedly used to eliminate subversive elements.

- General Alvarez is deposed amid anti-American demonstrations in Tegucigalpa. US-run training camps for Salvadoran counter-revolutionaries are shut down, but the government continues to cooperate with the US administration's anti-Sandinista activities in return for substantial economic aid.
- Another Liberal Party man, Jose Azcona del Hoyo, elected president after the law was changed to stipulate a maximum one-term presidency.
- Amnesty granted both to military and left-wing guerrillas for abuses committed during early 1980s.
Hundreds of juvenile gangs - or maras - operate in Honduras
February - An Amnesty International report alleges an increase in human rights violations by armed forces and right-wing death squads.
August - Inter-American Court of Human Rights finds Honduran government guilty of "disappearances" of Honduran citizens between 1981 and 1984.
January - General Alvarez is assassinated by left-wing guerrillas in Tegucigalpa.
February - Summit of Central American presidents in El Salvador reaches agreement on demobilisation of Nicaraguan Contras based in Honduras.
January - Rafael Callejas sworn in as president; proceeds to introduce neo-liberal economic reforms and austerity measures.
June - Last Nicaraguan Contras leave Honduras.
- International Court of Justice gives ruling establishing new boundaries between Honduras and El Salvador.
March - Government sets up commission to investigate alleged human rights violations by military.
November - Liberal Party candidate and veteran rights activist Carlos Reina elected president. Reina pledges to reform judicial system and limit power of armed forces.
April - Compulsory military service abolished.
July - First military officers charged with human rights abuses.
- Carlos Flores of the Liberal Party elected president; pledges to restructure armed forces.
May - Control of police transferred from military to civilian authorities, but reports of rights abuses continue.
October - Hurricane Mitch devastates Honduras.
- Armed forces placed under civilian control.
November - Congress ratifies 1986 maritime agreement with Colombia settling claims over the Caribbean Sea. This upsets Nicaragua, which claims some of the area as its own.
December - Honduras and Nicaragua agree to halt ground troop deployments and pull out naval forces from the Caribbean sea pending resolution of a border dispute.
June - Supreme Court rules that atrocities committed during 1980s are not covered by amnesty of 1987.
January - Honduran Committee for the Defence of Human Rights says more than 1,000 street children were murdered in 2000 by death squads backed by the police.
August - UN calls on government to prevent extrajudicial killings of hundreds of children and teenagers, some at the hands of police officers.
January - Ricardo Maduro inaugurated as president. He says armed forces will play greater role in fighting crime. Declaration is greeted with dismay at home and abroad.
Hundreds of juvenile gangs - or maras - operate in Honduras
January - Honduras re-establishes diplomatic ties with Cuba which it severed in 1961 when Cuba was expelled from Organisation of American States.
May - Congress votes to send troops to Iraq, making Honduras the first Central American country to authorise a deployment.
December - Honduras - along with Guatemala, El Salvador and Nicaragua - agrees on a free trade agreement with the US.
May - Prison fire at San Pedro Sula kills more than 100 inmates, many of them gang members.
Honduran troops withdraw from Iraq.
December - Suspected gang members massacre 28 bus passengers in the northern city of Chamalecon.
November - Tropical Storm Gamma kills more than 30 people and forces tens of thousands from their homes.
December - Liberal Party's Manuel Zelaya is declared the winner of presidential elections after his ruling party rival concedes defeat.
April - Free trade deal with the US comes into effect. The Honduran Congress approved the Central American Free Trade Agreement (Cafta) in March 2005.
Honduras and neighbouring El Salvador inaugurate their newly-defined border. The countries fought over the disputed frontier in 1969.
May - President Zelaya orders all the country's radio and TV stations to carry government propaganda for two hours a day for 10 days to counteract what he says is a campaign of misinformation.
October - The International Court of Justice in the Hague settles a long-running territorial dispute between Honduras and Nicaragua.

President Manuel Zelaya visits Cuba, the first official trip by a Honduran president to the island in 46 years. The two countries recently agreed their maritime boundaries after a long-running dispute.

August - Longtime US ally Honduras joins the Bolivarian Alternative for the Americas (ALBA), an alliance of leftist leaders in Latin America headed by Venezuelan President Hugo Chavez, a staunch US foe. President Manuel Zelaya says a lack of international support to tackle chronic poverty forced him to seek aid from Venezuela.
June - President Manuel Zelaya is removed by the military and forced into exile. Coup is widely condemned. Organisation of American States (OAS) suspends Honduras.
September - Mr Zelaya makes a surprise return to Honduras, taking refuge in the Brazilian embassy in Tegucigalpa.
November - Porfirio "Pepe" Lobo Sosa of the conservative National Party wins presidential election.
December - Congress rejects proposal that Mr Zelaya be allowed to return to office.
January - Mr Zelaya goes into exile in the Dominican Republic. Supreme Court dismisses charges against six military commanders who expelled Mr Zelaya from the country in June 2009.
February - Government says it has restored diplomatic ties with 29 countries following its isolation after the coup.
March - US resumes aid programme suspended after the coup, saying President Porfirio Lobo was democratically elected.
May - "Truth commission" begins investigating Mr Zelaya's removal from office in 2009, and concludes it was a coup.
November - International Criminal Court investigates allegations of human rights abuses during the 2009 coup.
December - Mexico, Honduras agree to work together to prevent attacks on illegal migrants from Honduras, many of whom are kidnapped on their way to the US.
May - Mr Zelaya returns from exile.
December - Congress votes to allow troops to take on police duties in a bid to tackle the high murder rate. US Peace Corps says it is withdrawing its volunteers due to rising insecurity.
February - Fire in the overcrowded Comayagua prison kills 358.
April - Rural workers take part in coordinated land invasions across the country.
May - Thousands march to protest wave of violence against journalists - more than 20 of whom have been killed in the past three years.
The two most notorious street gangs in Honduras - the Mara Salvatrucha and the Mara Dieciocho - agree a truce, promising to end the violence which has claimed tens of thousands of lives.
January - Juan Orlando Hernandez takes over as president.
May - In the first extradition of a Honduran to the United States, Honduras hands over a wanted suspected drug lord Carlos Arnoldo Lobo.

June - The US boosts aid and speeds up deportations to cope with the growing number of migrants from Central America. Honduras, Guatemala, and El Salvador are to receive millions of dollars to combat gang violence and help citizens repatriated from the US.
October - The Red Cross says more than half a million people in Honduras have been affected by a severe drought, and launches an appeal for funds to assist them.
April - Congress passes a law offering special protection to journalists, human rights activists and judicial workers with the establishment of a panel under the justice to investigate threats.
April - The Supreme Court nullifies a law that prohibited presidents from serving more than one term.

June - Tens of thousands of Hondurans march in the capital, demanding the resignation of President Juan Orlando Hernandez over opposition claims he received millions of dollars from the country's public health system for his 2013 election campaign.
February - An international mission aimed at tackling widespread corruption in Honduras is installed with a four-year mandate.
March - Indigenous leader and respected environmental rights activist Berta Caceres is killed by gunmen at her home in Esperanza, some 200 km from the capital Tegucigalpa.
March - Former President Rafael Callejas pleads guilty to two counts of bribery and fraud related to the FIFA corruption scandal.
November - Disputed presidential election. Incumbent Juan Orlando Hernandez is declared winner.
Removal of Zelaya 'Honduras coup'
Legacies of Rebellion- Honduras
Honduras struggles 10 years after Mitch
